summary: Thirteen Lives recounts the incredible true story of the tremendous global effort to rescue a Thai soccer team who become trapped in the Tham Luang cave during an unexpected rainstorm. Faced with insurmountable odds, a team of the world's most skilled and experienced divers -- uniquely able to navigate the maze of flooded, narrow cave tunnels -- join with Thai forces and more than 10,000 volunteers to attempt a harrowing rescue of the twelve boys and their coach. With impossibly high stakes and the entire world watching, the group embarks on their most challenging dive yet, showcasing the limitlessness of the human spirit in the process.

reviews.content: Beautiful movie, it's long but you don't feel it! highly recommended

A well-directed and compelling re-telling of an outstanding miracle rescue. The film is well-acted and does a great job displaying the near-impossible mission the SEALs pulled off together to rescue the boys.

94%. This movie is incredible from the start where the team and coach are practicing together and then they quickly are missing and the rescue mission starts right away. Moving story of people from 17 different countries combining efforts to save them. The whole diving team and the people diverting the water to give the boys more time in the cave. Amazing film. Would rewatch tomorrow
I really enjoyed it. It's been a few months so I don't remember exactly what I thought, except that it was a good movie.
I'm surprised I didn't know of this film. Looks like it was lost in the shuffle when Amazon bought MGM. It wasn't really promoted. It's really good.

Thirteen Lives is very well constructed, intensely real film about a heroic mission that succeeded against all odds. Veteran director Ron Howard always makes film that are both well made and also very watchable. His latest is no exception. Based on the huge news story of 2018 this film tells the story straight forwardly and honestly and that makes it work. The story was the Thai Cave mining rescue operation. 13 people, 12 teenage boys and their soccer coach, went into remote caves in Northern Thailand but become stranded when immense rain floods the caves. They survive initally for 10 days before anyone can even sight them in the caves. Then a rescue mission is mounted, primarliy by two English divers, to get them out. This is a film about not just survival but also ingenuity and perseverance. Even though we know the outcome there are plenty of jaw dropping moments leading to a very emotional outcome. Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell are well cast as the taciturn divers. A film I think most people would gain from watching it.
Wow, how is this not nominated for everything. Ron Howard's best since Apollo 13. Thrilling, terrifying and gorgeously done.
Ron Howard returns back to form with a groundbreaking survival film filled with magnificent performances, prodigious cinematography and a riveting, awe-inspiring story about stellar heroism.
pretty good for me slow at some parts but thats the only critisism

The true tale of rescuing the trapped 13 Thai boys in the summer of 2018 is turned into an engrossing and often thrilling if overly long 2022 movie experience thanks to director Ron Howard and a dedicated crew bringing to vivid life the harrowing drama. I was vaguely aware of this story as it played out originally, though missed the critically acclaimed documentary The Rescue from last year that covered the same material, but watching the movie I realize I knew very little of the actual horror. The movie centers around a pair of English divers (Colin Farrell, Viggo Mortensen), both with over 30 years of specific cave diving experience, helping the Thai Navy Seals and government officials to find and save the missing children and their coach. The submerged path is one that lasts about seven hours, and it's narrow, dark, and treacherous, easy to lose your way. when you only have a tank of air, navigation is the difference between life and death. It's also a race against time as the monsoon waters are flooding the cave further. The cave traversal sequences are nerve-wracking and deeply immersive, enough so that even I, while watching, started sitting on the edge of my couch in the safety of my own home. The story isn't entirely centered on our two heroic white guys, as the screenplay by William Nicholson (Gladiator) widens the focus onto many who contributed to the boys eventual rescue, from an engineer who realized they needed to dam water drainage at the top of a mountain, to the locals who agreed to have their crops flooded for the possibility of saving the kids, to the bravery of the Thai Seals, to the hope and burdens of the parents. I never knew the boys had to literally be anesthetized to be removed, and the ensuring climax as the rescue team keeps tabs on how their precious cargo is responding during the multi-hour journey underwater. Howard keeps things pretty straightforward and helpfully provides onscreen graphics to better provide a sense of distance within the cave, which just makes the heroics even more dizzying. Thirteen Lives is an inspiring story about the world coming together for common cause (except Elon Musk, who baselessly accused one of the divers as being a "pedo") and it's also genuinely exciting even when you know they all make it out alive, which is its own credit. It might have used some tightening up for pacing, but it's a well-made dramatization that pays real homage to the many heroes without overplaying its drama.

Nate's Grade: B+

Whether you already know what happens or not, this movie will have you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Also kudos to this movie's lighting department. The whole thing takes place either in a cave, in the rain, or at night (sometimes all at once), and I never, ever had trouble seeing the action of this movie.
Wonderful movie, great actors also asian one reaaaly good

I knew of the story and read a detailed article about it but it didn't matter at all that I knew how it turned out....it was still moving and powerful.  It is well acted and moved quickly.  Good one, Ron Howard.

As someone who has never seen the Rescue, i thought Thirteen Lives was an incredibly impactful movie. Ron Howard doesnt always deliver, but this time he really does. So first of all, this movie needs to get some technical academy award nominations, at least for sound, incredible work. The VFX in this movie are invisible, the cinematography is pretty good, the production design is incredible and the camerawork is fantastic. I thought Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell did an incredible job as the cave divers, as well as the rest of the cast, it really didnt feel like a movie, more like a documentary of the rescue mission. The movie really tries to respect the divers, family and everyone else involved in the rescue of the football time and sometimes that hurts the characters and the dialog a bit, but for this situation i can understand it. Overall an impactfull technical movie, with of course an story which will forever be incredible.
I'm surprised I haven't heard more about this movie, it is so good. Excellent. I highly recommend.

Very interesting from a historical documentation perspective, but this movie suffers because it can't decide if it's a documentary or a movie. This would have been better if it was just a documentary.
So good.  I knew the outcome and still was a nervous wreck.
It's a must see for an in depth view of what the children, families and rescues went thru and did to save the boys. It's awe inspiring.
Loved this movie! Pulled you in and kept you watching. I remember when this happened but had no idea of the real/indepth story. All the actors were supurb
For such an amazing true story this film is surprisingly dull.

Silently breathtaking. The thoughts that I had as a mother couldn't escape me as I considered what those children must be suffering: alone, cold and wet and in near complete darkness, hungry, scared, afraid they had left their parents down. The country came together and the world came together. What I had not realized was that the boys and coach were sedated in order to "pack them out" like gear. I saw the fear and misgivings in each actors' eyes and their emotions flowed into mine. The real life Stanton, Harris, Jewell, Volanthen, and Mallinson were the world's best cave divers but never had they had to consider, and ultimately carry out this unprecedented rescue. Ron Howard did another wonderful job in putting the viewer into the eyes of the divers, the souls of the parents, the hearts of the people of Thailand, and the wherewithal of the many, many volunteers who came to help, whether it was cooking, making pipe with bamboo poles, damming holes, or just watching their crops and livelihood literally wash away in order to save these children.

A well-directed and compelling re-telling of an outstanding miracle rescue. The film is well-acted and does a great job displaying the near-impossible mission the SEALs pulled off together to rescue the boys.

Ron Howard delivers a gem of a movie by taking you right into the middle of the action. Outstanding production with top-of-the-line acting and a tight script. Right from the first scene to the end, it keeps you on the edge of your seat. Based on a true story that recently happened in northern Thailand. A soccer team comprising 12 boys and their coach gets stuck deep inside a tunnel cave that gets flooded in Thailand. With no hope of escape, the movie shows how people from different parts of the world and the locals work together to overcome great odds... Great movie to enjoy with your family.
A little too long but it was very well done. An amazing/tragic story of bravery. Ron Howard always makes great movies and never disappoints.

Thirteen Lives takes a meticulous dive into the insane rescue operation conducted by cave divers to extract thirteen lives out of a flooded cave in Northern Thailand. The great thing about this film compared to the other adaptations is the focus on diving. It is only here that you get the true sense of what the divers had to go through and how good they were in order to do it. Making it a solid story

A medium-good natural disaster rescue film, one to watch and cry over with family. Not more than once, though - the actors are underperforming a bit, one would typically expect more from actors such as Mortensen and Farrell. That said, the scenes are quite realistic - that and the drama evolving among simple people of the local community wins the story.
This was a great dramatization which was entertaining while staying fairly true to actual events
Best movie I have seen in ages,the drama,so tense at times, plus I didn't realize just how much effort went into this rescue, the actors did an awesome job

Ron Howard somehow creates tension and expectation even when you know how this true life story ends. Taking young boys underwater through caves to their rescue sets off some crazy claustrophobic nerves.
This was one of the best movies I've ever seen. The acting is phenomenal and the story is nothing short of a miracle. This is a must see.
Thirteen Lives does an amazing job of maintaining a high level of suspense, even though the outcome will be known to most people. The details of the worldwide effort to save the 13 are fascinating.
Critic's are idiots to say this was not a great flix...outstanding
An amazing story which exhibits the best in humanity.

Ron Howard has been churning out excellent films that have been a favourite with audiences, movies like Splash, Cocoon, Willow, Parenthood, Backdraft, Apollo 13, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, A Beautiful Mind, The Da Vinci Code, Frost/Nixon, Rush, In the Heart of the Sea. Hollywood has never much cared for him. He's had just one nomination as director for Frost/Nixon. I think this is because you don't watch a Ron Howard movie and think "Ah, this is clearly a Ron Howard movie". He's just quietly professional. He doesn't leave his own mark on the way the story is told. He tells the story the way he feels it should be told, which is different each time. I wish more directors were like Ron Howard. Just professional. Far too many directors are trying to be the next bit thing, the next Scorsese, Coppola, and failing. There's much to be said for just doing a great job.

In this film Ron Howard tells the story as a straight docu-drama. There is a bit of the old "shaky-cam" going on which by now everybody detests, but it seems to  fade into the background over time. This is a big, big story and with 10,000 people involved there are far too many people with stories to tell in a movie that is 2 and a half hours long. Consequently the action tends to focus on the British and Australian divers, who with expertise gained from similar rescues were able to pull off a seemingly impossible task of raising these boys from the depths of the mountain through 3 hours of crawling through underground tubes of rock filled with water. It really brings home the impossibility of these boys having survived in this underground bubble of air in the first place, as well as the impossibility of bringing them to the surface as more rain threatens to come and flood the cave entirely. 

According to reports, the film is entirely accurate except for one detail - it shows the cave water as being clear. This is obviously for the purposes of showing the underwater action as the divers, boys and air cylinders are squeezed through the tiniest of gaps, but it is certainly worth noting that the apparently impossible rescue was carried out in water so thick with mud that the divers lights were almost useless as they could see absolutely nothing. With that in mind the diver Vern was more crucial to the rescue than suggested in the film, with his pre-prepared divers map being the only thing that indicated where the divers in the flooded cave would be going. 

There is one twist in the tale that I wasn't aware of. We were told at the time that the boys were taught how to use diving equipment and then swam out of the cave themselves. That, it turns out, was not the case, and the story at the time was a cover for what actually happened. 

Colin Farrell and Viggo Mortensen do an unbelievable job of portraying divers Rick Stanton and John Volanthen and I have no doubt that is exactly as Mr Stanton and Mr Volanthen are as people. 

A fantastic true-life story and filmed exactly as it should've been filmed by Ron Howard. Worth watching by everybody. Don't be put off by the long running time - it felt like half the time when the story unfolded.

While not nearly as incredible as the documentary (The Rescue), the dramatization of some of the events, particularly the unfortunate death of the SEAL added something the documentary did not have.  13 Lives however lacked some of the hard-edged and raw pessimism that the documentary showed so well.  Had I not already seen The Rescue it might have been different, but I still have to say the film is well worth the 150 minutes.
What an amazing movie based heavily on the true story of this soccer team.  This was a well written script and keeps you engaged through out.

This is a great movie.  Amazing technical shooting, and the actors did the dive scenes themselves to bring the realism to a whole new level.  Yes, a few of the actual events are slightly condensed or emphasized for the sake of cinematic flow, but wow.  It's gripping, claustrophobic, and the oncoming monsoon rains are the equivalent of a ticking bomb.  Great acting, with dialogue that is appropriately sparse for the middle-aged British characters, yet full with meaning.  It's riveting to watch the drama of it, even though you know how it ends.

It's long but it gives the real sense of the slowest progress made. Wonderful acting by many, including Thai actors, specially the governor. Ron Howard managed to keep everything low key on a documentary scale with no fuss.  Colin Farrell absolutely remarkable, but pretty much everyone else. Incredibly moving at times.  The end of one of the divers, and the farmers decision. Ron Howard should be proud.

A fantastic film showing the monumental effort involved, the challenges faced, the costs involved and brought to the screen in such a manner that you become completely immersed and increasingly drawn in as the rescue progresses to its final conclusion

In 2018, the harrowing rescue of the soccer team trapped in the Tham Luang cave was all over the news. Four years later, this dramatic retelling of those 18 days has finally hit the big screen (well, at least on Amazon Prime). While the film does a great job of showing the inside view of the true events, there is not much more substance to it. The film does have some tense moments that are truly anxiety-inducing, but there is never a moment where the full gravity of the situation is felt.

The story is awe-inspiring. Ron Howard is a great director. Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell and Joel Edgerton are great actors. Taking all that into account, "Thirteen Lives" is a good movie. The screenplay stuck to the source material and illustrated the events that took place. Unfortunately, there isn't much more depth to it. Simply put, "Thirteen Lives" is best described as a no-nonsense film.

Best Character: Dr. Harry
Best Quote: "Fear is created in our minds." - The Coach
Best Scene: The first discovery
Very engaging and entertaining. I don't usually like this "based on true events" genre but this was excellent. Great performances from all involved, especially Viggo.
By-the-book event movie with a compelling enough story to keep you interested.
Strong acting, incredible true story, heartfelt!
We know what's coming, but Ron Howard draws us in so completely that the movie never lags and keeps us on the edge of our proverbial seats.

Decent, but not as gripping as the documentary on the same topic: "The Rescue". 

And for all those reviewers objecting to the toxic white males in the film: get over it. The boys were rescued by white English and Australian male divers. Not women. Not black people. Not brown people. Not lesbians. Not any of the people promoted in the diversity olympics. 

The world needs more toxic white males like this. Sorry if that doesn't fit with your post-modern revisionist view of humanity.

I was glued to this story as it unfolded, literally stayed up through the nights, even checked the weather reports! I didn't know about the death of the second guy. Those 2 deaths are so very very sad against an absolutely remarkable rescue. The film just sticks to the facts. At first I wondered why they didn't use English actors but Viggo is one of my favourites and Colin was great. Fantastic film about an unbelievable feat. Such a good watch. I literally burst into tears at the first sight of the boys in the cave. Positive, truthful and well made.
Super interesting and moving, I held my breathe many times while watching!

Oh my, where do I start? The ratings on RT hyped my expectations a tad, but this was a boring, single viewed account of the event. We got to know exactly ZERO about the main focus of the film, the ordeal of the pre-teen to teenage boys and their coach miraculously surviving over a week without food in dark caves, with no communication with the outside world. An epic fail, and not to mention equally single dimensional portraits of their families and their own ordeal. Instead we got repetitive fake documentary footage of (mostly foreign white) men diving in dark bubbly tunnels.
You feel many different emotions during this movie.  Absolutely gripping!

I am not fair on Ron Howard - not that he would care the slightest bit for my opinion. I have him filed away in my mind as a safe pair of hands, a bit dull and prone to sentimentality. Sometimes true - but by no means always. I feared a film like this, telling a genuinely remarkable true story which we all know  - would play to the worst of those. The reverse is true. It brings out the best in Howard and those around him; it's understated in the best ways, there's a lack of sentimentality which makes it all the more moving, and it's success stems at least in part from an unpredictable creative decision which pays off well. Movies about disasters like to - need to, in fact - lay on a spectacular disaster. This doesn't show us any of that - perhaps because the involvement of children might have made it somehow exploitative  - and instead focuses on the widespread relief effort and the emotional toll on those involved. Most impressively it eschews a classic trap of these films - there is not a hint of the white saviour about all this. The breadth of those involved is always well portrayed, and no one person is in charge or more heroic than anyone else. Local customs, rituals and religion are to the fore. It packs a subtly powerful emotional punch, and it speaks to something deeper by choosing a path less often trod by these sorts of films.

I got a rotten tomatoes account just to write my 5 star review for this movie lol. This was one of, if not my favorite movie of all time. Absolutely amazing from start to finish! I will say though, I didn't know much of the backstory of the real-life events that this movie is based off of so it was probably more nuanced for me. The documentary on this was excellent too, I watched it after and enjoyed it equally.
You'll be holding your breath for at least two and a half hours in this gripping dramatisation of a miracle true story that features outstanding acting and gorgeous cinematography.

A solid claustrophobic tense true story about 12 boys and a coach who are trapped in a cave in Thailand.  I didn't know anything about this, which was helpful.  It made the story fresh and even more should keep the viewer on the edge of their seat.  The stars all do what you expect, but it's Ron Howard and his ability to tell a story in a way that everyone can enjoy that make this entertaining and not just repetitive.  He just gets how to make a movie and with a real drama that stands alone, like this one, Howard's skill shines even more.  While it could have been shaved closer to 2-hours (the film drags at times), you're rewarded with a paint by numbers charmer in the 3rd act.  Final Score: 8/10

Is there anybody better than Ron Howard who can make a movie seem so real you think you're watching a documentary?  You know the story, so spend a couple of hours in the murky cave depths and appreciate the heroism of all concerned.

The movie is long, however, we were riveted, great acting, emotional and wow the filming under water was excruciatingly on point. We loved it. A true story of determination which took us beautifully throughout he true-life events.
awesome movie, i recommend it with all my heart!!

It was emotional without letting those emotions runs out of control. Even if you knew, generally, what the end result was, you still wanted to know what's next. Most people, I think, don't really know how they did it and the extraordinary lengths that they went to in order to save 13 Lives. Hours after the movie it's still running through my thoughts and reinforcing my understanding of the importance of all life.

Thirteen Lives is a fantastic bio-film about the actual event which we all followed those days. What makes it good is the real drama happening in the movie. Still hard to believe and process how they save those kids. Acting, tension... Everything is perfect.

This one was hard to stay engaged with. Maybe because we saw it all over the news and we already know the outcome. 

They did a good job on highlighting some of the challenges of traversing through caves for long distances and the massive challenge of dragging drugged up kids out of the caves. 
Worth watching at least once.
A bit slow, bit good! Kept very close to the story itself
Wow. What a great story. Well told, well acted, well filmed. Amazing movie.

This film is a masterpiece! I was enthralled from start to finish. It so beautifully told a tale which we were watching, praying and hoping for a positive outcome. Amazing film… it captures the many stakeholders involved and how it was an effort on so many fronts. I completely loved every moment.
Great movie. I had no idea the sheer magnitude of this event! It was amazing to see a movie not amped up with over the top effects. A gripping story and great performances from the cast
Fantastic adaptation and fantastic movie witha lots of emotions...best survival movie
Powerful drama, telling more to the story than I was initially aware of . The bravery of all involved is humbling
absolutely amazing movie. really touching and makes you reflect on the importance of life and how humanity treats it nowadays. beautifully done. viggo mortensen's acting was phenomenal in this.

Look, it's nothing revolutionary. It's a pretty standard true story film, especially for Ron Howard. But I'd be lying if I said the film didn't make me feel something! It's a gripping, intense and emotionally charged film of an incredible true story… however when considering the documentary that came before this… that was a better account of events. Hell, the only reason this movie really works and was so gripping and emotional is because it was a true story. It's just amazing to see what the human spirit can do, but the movie rides off the emotions of the true story and does nothing really creative itself. There's nothing to explore character-wise, and it plays literally like a dramatized version of the documentary. It's fine and good, it does work and it has impact, I just didn't think it was as strong as it could be, especially considering the incredible documentary made on this subject. The movie is also way too long, it didn't need to be 2.5 hours. I liked Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell's performances, and Ron Howard's direction is good (not as good as he used to be though). Overall it's a decent re-telling of an incredible true story. It's worth a watch, especially if you'd rather watch a narrative film over a documentary, and while I think the documentary is better, it's undeniable that this does do a good job telling the story and making you feel it's impact.
One of the best movies of the year. Beautifully done, exceptionally well told. You won't be disappointed.

I was aware of the real story but didn't know the details. The movie was unexpectedly brilliant with great performances all around - I found myself invested in the story despite knowing how it ends. 

Highly recommend!
Brilliant depiction of the rescue and how the morality of sedating them ( which I wasn't aware of) was questioned and ultimately the only answer.

In 2018, 12 boys and their coach found themselves in the international spotlight when news broke globally about their entrapment deep within a system of caves in Northern Thailand that were flooded by the early arrival of monsoon season. The ensuing rescue mission that lasted over 2 weeks has now earned a Hollywood dramatization, capably directed by Ron Howard, which depicts how the rescuers, in particular a bunch of predominantly British cave-diving volunteers (underplayed by Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell) who have the necessary skills to navigate the treacherous underground/water terrains and who also hatch a risky plan to transport them back to safety. The film is a surprisingly tense though straightforward and conventional 2½ hours that is restraint enough to convey the frustration and pressure involved without resorting to hysteria or melodrama; and sensitive and inclusive enough not to be just another portrayal of the Caucasian heroes coming in to save the day. Diligently recreating the claustrophobic and dangerous conditions the rescuers face, they've managed to make rainwater and undercurrents into a visual peril that the audience can understand and appreciate by showing the extensive damage it can cause or the consequences of either inexperience or just bad luck under the circumstances. Tension is further ramped up with visual aids that pop up intermittently at crucial moments to inform us precisely of the time and geography of each critical manoeuvre. Howard has proven success with the similar Apollo 13, where the outcome is already known to most viewers, yet it's the details we learn that aren't previously known that make it engaging and tense; and our knowledge of how it turned out works somewhat in its favour in the end, as we feel safe enough to enjoy the film without feeling guilty that we're simply indulging in disaster porn.
Straight forward story telling. No hidden social agenda, no search for a hidden truth. Just the facts with top notch director and actors. Need a feel good movie? This is it!

Half these stars are just for Viggo Mortensen. I really recommend this movie. It is a tight plot and the actors do a good job. In general this movie is a must see because it shows viewers that humans can still solve big problems when we work together, are sufficiently organized, and do not get distracted by the giant clown car that is modern global society. It loses 1 half a point because it ignores the faith based component of the rescue, specifically the transcendental meditation used by the boys to survive without food for ELEVEN DAYS. Hollywood needs to stop turning every hero into a secular aristocrat who drinks expensive wine and lives in a mansion in West Hampton.  Otherwise a good movie.
Great movie the whole family can watch.  It was tense, scary, sad, hopeful, and ultimate triumphant.
Amazing men and boys. Very emotional show beautifully done.

I usually hate true life stories turned into movies.  But Ron Howard has made another masterpiece.  Apollo 13 was more visually stimulating, and arguably a better movie.  However, Ron Howard is a master of the true life story movie genre, and this movie deserves praise...
Excellent! Feel like we are really there.
True hero's actions celebrated in this wonderful movie with a stellar cast and crew !!!
This was one fantastic movie. Not an easy accomplishment when you know it's a true story and you're already familiar with the ending.

Uunexpectedly good movie, in comparison with a modern movies of recent years, such as Amazon, Netflix, Hollywood.  Also great acting performance. 
10/10
Wow, great storytelling. And what great set pieces.

Inspiring adaptation of the true story.  I remember seeing this in the news but never realized how big of a task it was to get them out to safety.  Loved seeing how the community, and people from around the world worked to make this happen. Great job.

I was riveted to this story in 2018 but was not riveted to this movie. It didn’t build any sense of connection and passion for the boys in the cave. Ten days in the cave as portrayed in the movie seemed like the boys were in there 45 minutes. The best part of the movie was the illustration of the process used to get the boys out to safety. I don’t understand all the 5 star reviews. Didn’t work for me.
Griping, unbelievable and heart warming.
This is a pretty solid effort from Ron Howard. Well worth a watch via streaming.
Really well acted and paced overall.
By far the most emotional and thrilling movie of 2022. We have all seen the news of this rescue and this movie captures the heroics and moving scenes perfectly.
Well produced. Riveting true story.
I remember the event but never really knew about the details.  Thanks to this movie, I got to see how the event unfolded in an entertaining and dramatic fashion.
Outstanding acting and a compelling story.  I really liked this movie.

Amazing story displayed in a visually stunning and emotionally captivating way. Bravo for telling the truth and not shoehorning contemporary signals into the film. Perfect length to tell the full story. Refreshing!
Actually really great. Enjoyed the entire watch-through. Definitely worth the time if you're looking for something new to watch!
Apollo 13 underground. And that's a good thing!

Thirteen Lives shares the untold story that took place behind the scenes of the daring rescue mission that dominated headlines in 2018 to save a group of young boys and their coach from the Tham Luang cave in Thailand. The film is gripping from start to finish, offering viewers an intense thrill ride as the events unfold. Director Ron Howard depicts what happened candidly without omitting disreputable details while highlighting the courage and sacrifice of the men and women who came together to triumph over the impossible.

It's not perfect, some actors not always seems to be implicated. But it's very well directed, it's give you emotion.

Good movie for a streaming platform, no more, no less.

This is based on a somewhat recent true story, one I remember hearing about on the news at the time. Its well made and certainly is quite tense and gripping at times, even though viewers will likely know the ultimate outcome. I reckon if your prone to claustrophobia then this is best avoided, as I felt it was quite atmospheric and they don't shy away from portraying the perilous situation the kids (and their coach) found themselves in. 

I found myself respecting the decisions and actions of the various cave rescue workers/volunteers, given what they were putting on the line and having to think up new solutions, or potential solutions, to try and rescue those stuck alive. I can only imagine how frustrating it must have been for the series of events that happens, the relationship between the volunteers/specialists and the media circus that gathers. Its a sobering watch and it'd be hard not to feel sorry, to one extent or another, to people in both sides of the proverbial camps I feel. It is a long film and I did feel less engaged at times, which maybe says more about my attention span than anything else (I'm annoyingly easily distracted at times). I noticed it often states on screen a duration and location, relating to where, I assume, the workers were - it didn't make sense to me initially that it seemed to say, for example, '8 hours 15 minutes' as if thats how long said 13 people had been stuck there, when I knew there were foreign helpers attempting to reach them - it would likely have taken over 8 hours for some of them to have reached the local area. That's perhaps my fault for not paying as much attention as I should have.

I note that at first the British cave rescue helpers/workers were almost laughing off the situation in Thailand, which is frustrating to view. There's a sentiment (almost precisely these words) about 'well if they managed to get there, surely they can get themselves back out again as well' (seriously, its as simple as that?!). I can't comment how exaggerated or not that was - quite probably those used to working in different sorts of rescue scenarios may shrug off such an incident, given it wasn't (it'd seem) a situation that often happens.

Ron Howard has done well to treat the story with respect, I feel and I appreciate that the film does feature a fair amount (not exclusively but a fair bit) of the local language (Thai) and that there are numerous Thai characters, rather than it being entirely a list, Hollywood and British actors on screen. I think if this story intrigues you and the cast interests you then yes, I'd recommend this.

Despite having read about the story when it was in the news cycle, I still didn't grasp the magnitude of the Tham Luang Nang Non cave rescue. "Gripping" and "unbelievable" doesn't begin to describe the actual events this film portrays. 

Howard's film is mostly accurate but leaves out a whole lot of details to make the story more dramatic—there were actually two divers escorting each of the thirteen trapped soccer team members out of the cave and roughly ninety divers stationed along the entire route to provide medical checkups and assistance. Also not shown were the 110 Thai Navy Seals and divers from around the world who had tried and failed to reach the boys before the expert cave divers were called in.

Overall, a superb film about an incredible true story.

What a crazy movie! The attention to detail is surreal and seeing them swimming and diving through small spaces and it paints into perspective of how it kinda was. They probably changed some stuff but it seems legit. But what could've been an even better movie is if It was through the 12 kids and their coach's perspective. That would've been crazy to see what they have done to survive. I highly doubt all they did was mediate for days. It's kinda crazy to think that these kids have the discipline for how many days again? Is it 10 days? Anyway it was a long long time and if I had to do that, I highly doubt I could. Those kids have guts. But again it would've been better if it was through their perspective or if it switched between them and the adults. In the end this is a great movie and I highly recommend.

Compelling from start to finish.  I watched it twice in 24 hours.  Convincingly real, terrifying,uplifting and fascinating. Strap yourself in for a rollercoaster ride through the world of cave diving rescue.

Inspiring and intriguing plot, with a cast that does things very well. The suffocating scenarios and moments that the characters go through stand out a lot. You have to appreciate the magnificent work with the sound mix, which makes the film more intriguing and suspenseful.
Superb movie which emotionally captures the actions of great men who put their own lives on the live to save thirteen young boys. Truly heroic.

Possibly the best rescue movie I have watched.  They did a great job capturing the difficulty the divers faced.  The actors could not have done a better job portraying the physical and emotional toll of each dive.  The only way it could have been more suspenseful is if it wasn't the biggest story worldwide and I didn't know how it ended. 
 Don't watch if you are claustrophobic.
This movie is peak!I dont usually find prime video movies exciting but danm this was so good.This also is 99 percent factual.
INCREDIBLE FILM! One of the most gripping films i've ever watched, I would recommend it to everyone!
I feel so weird suffocated while watching. . .
If you give this anything less than 5 stars there is something wrong with you.

Kudos to Ron Howard and company for keeping this movie real without the Hollywood drama. This is not a superhero movie. It's about the 5000+ volunteers who showed up for 2 1/2 weeks while the rest of the world was watching, hoping and praying, for a good outcome. Mission accomplished, at all levels!

Really good movie! It seems a little like a documentary, but only the best aspects of a documentary that are mixed with great drama. I had forgotten a lot of the details of this incident, and found myself repeatedly tensing up during suspenseful moments during the movie. I'd highly recommend it.
One of the best movies I've seen in years!! Unbelievable that really happened. Amazing cast. A must see

One of the best suspense films I have seen - I was on the edge of my seat for most of it. It's still haunting me today. If it were fiction I'd have turned it off thinking it was quite ridiculous. But the fact that this actually happened.... unbelievable!
Best rescue and servival movie every...

This is a movie about placing yourself in the characters shoes and feeling pretty emotional about the outcome of the events, which everyone should definitely check out to relive the experience. I don't understand the people who saw it, that "claim" that the movie is bland. The movie will pull you over. Most movies include cheesy and boring drama, that fall apart quickly and be forgettable, this one doesn't include any cheesy acting. 10 out of 10 rating.
Incredibly well-directed movie
One of the best movies I've seen. Good story but very stressful. Definitely would watch it again and I would definitely recommend it for a family movie night.

Very compelling story. I won't praise the screenwriters much because all of the work had been done for them. That said, the cast and crew definitely show up here. Although the script doesn't call for phenomenal Oscar-worthy performances, Mortenson, Farrell, Edgerton, and the rest keep you invested and make everything feel real. Howard's direction is probably the real winner here, as he consistently keeps you on the edge of your seat. The cinematography is also astounding, making great use of the beautiful Thai landscape. All in all, this is a very strong film. Highly recommend.
This movie came out of nowhere.  Unbelievable story telling.  Great claustrophobic cinematography.

Gave me a sinking feeling. If you watched the documentary ‘The Rescue' then give this a miss. I was really hoping for some background to the characters and how the boys coped each day - nothing.  The script, acting and direction is pedestrian. I expected more from Colin Farrell and Ron Howard. The original documentary was far better. Very disappointing. 😞
Ron Howard hits it out of the park again. 13 Lives is gripping and intense. Definitely worth the watch

The filme Build with a positive point of view. More than the previous filme (The cave) only  focus on the controversy of the agency that received the fascination. Bring only the negative image of the governor (responsible for the area) drama and there are too many negative aspects.
  But with this filme that created  It looks like it's got a lot of positive energy. more accessible to the souls of the people Very well kept in detail. Watched 2 times. It really fills the heart.
Brilliant,  loved it.
It's a well-crafted account of an amazing true story.

It's quite good except the emotion of characters. I know Ron and his team want a realism as much as possible because it's based on the real miracle event but although that event is more drama than this movie.
it would of gotten a 5 if they would of showed the boys struggle to stay alive in the cave.

Where did those two and a half hours go, they went so quickly? How can a film you know the ending for be so thrilling? Tremendous viewing, loved the portrayal of the British and Thai characters. But I never want to go cave scuba diving!

An unbelievable story, told with incredible cinematography. It was horrifying, heart-wrenching and almost painfully captivating. As an experienced diver, I feel able to say the cave diving was portrayed so compellingly I found it difficult to breathe during some of the scenes and you will too. Please watch this, it was an absolutely mind blowing story. 13 Lives is not only an amazing movie- the actual details of the rescue are something no one should go about their lives without knowing. It restored some of my faith in humanity, which I say with all due gravity and sincerity. Incredible.
Never knew the children were sedated while being brought out by the divers. Thrillingly filmed despite the result is well known issue.

while watching I thought they surely must have exaggerated certain scenes or added certain things that didn't happen irl, it was just so unbelievable - but after doing some research I learned, no! It actually went down like this, almost scene by scene - that one diver actually did drop that syringe under water while the ''package'' was waking up, they actually were hog tied and sedated, that one boy actually did stop breathing again and again. it's absolutely mind-boggling what these divers did there and that it worked. 
If anything news reporting from back in 2018 portraited this rescue as far easier than it was. these men are heroes and this film tells their story brilliantly
Well worth watching. A truly incredible rescue. I thought at the time that the divers couldn't have possibly got the kids to swim out, seems I was right.

I cannot believe how good the production of this movie was. I can't wait to see "the making of 13 lives". Absolutely astonishing cinematography. I thought I'd never see something as good as Chernobyl, but today Ron Howard has done it. Ron is the best movie maker in the world.

A thoroughly gripping re-telling of the 2018 Thai cave rescue that I, like millions around the world followed from beginning to the triumphant end. Ron Howard was the natural choice to direct this film and the cast headed by Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell & Joel Edgerton was first class. Props should be given toany of the Thai cast who gave compelling  performances, conveying all the desperation and hope you'd expect from parents, officials and the Navy SEALs.

As a scuba diver this was a very heroic feat. I've been in tight situations but nothing like this!! I am extremely proud of the divers and the resilience of the boys and their coach. I have watched the documentaries and it just puts everything in more perspective. Ron Howard and team did an amazing job capturing the fear of what it's like diving in tight spaces, no visibility, and the elation of the rescue. I feel the movie was very well done. I was on the edge of my seat, gripping my chair and at times found myself holding my breath. I believe there has been a ridiculous amount of "oh how realistic was this" after watching the documentaries, it's very close to the true account of events and doesn't take away anything that was important. Maybe seeing the ones who stayed with the kids would have been good to include but I prob need to watch again maybe I missed something in my anxiety state. I will watch this movie again!
A beautiful movie, full of grace telling the story of these thirteen boys trapped in a cave we all heard about. The cast is absolutely on point, an absolute jewel from beginning to the end.
What a miraculous true story and an incredible film all around, from the visuals to the acting to the story telling, more than well done - masterful.
That was the best thriller movie on of this year
Thoughtful, tense and very well done.  A must watch for everyone!

Ron Howard tries to tell a heroic story, but bores us to death with its overlong 2,5 hour run-time of constantly doing the same thing with no real strong characters or drama. It all fell a little dry, and you should just watch the documentaries about it instead.
Followed the story as it happened.  The movie provided a poignant view of the difficulties and courage of the children and the rescuers.  First rate.
One of the Buddhist monks is wearing a wedding ring.  Buddhist monks don't marry, they are completely celibate.

Fascinating movie you watch until the end.  Ron Howard produces another gem.

Believe me when I had reservations about watching this movie.  Too many ways to mess it up.  Instead I watched it.  Well acted, well directed, and enough cave diving detail to give the viewer a sense of realism.  Without being overly theatrical.
Stayed awake the whole movie!
Incredible story and very well done by Mr. Howard.
Excellent filmography. Slow to start. Very touching. If you are claustrophobic remember to take slow deep breaths.
History said in vivid detail.
A deeply touching movie based on real events.  I loved it !
It's a solid 10/10 and a nail bitter throughout.  This is a must watch.
It keeps you on the edge of your seat. Equally thrilling and horrifying. Colin Farrell shines. Ron Howard delivered a true masterpiece.

I found my thrill, on Blueberry Hill. Too bad it was a day late and a dollar short.

I may have not minded as much if the 147 min runtime was chopped down to around 90-100 mins, but with the slow pacing, this was just too long and dragged out.

Sure, excellent cinematography, and amazing casting and performances, but nothing new or different from the docu-film The Rescue, which was just as well shot, and felt more authentic with the actual real-life rescuers and kids - and only 107 mins long.

I guess if you haven't seen the docu-film, you may enjoy this one more if you can sit through repetitive and slow dive scenes, and dull, drab, emotionless and uninspiring story-telling, with only Hollywood-styled impressive camera-work to look forward to. Howard's Blueberry Hill's thrill was 301 days too late and $55M too much.

A very compelling movie, but an incredible true story. However clearly not for everyone as a I've read from self proclaimed top critics that this movie focus to much on the white saviour.
To those critics I say this, those men who went into that cave did so because they wanted to help and would died to bring those kids out. To even try and throw slander at their efforts and remarkable bravery just goes to show how pathetic and pointless critics are. 
To even try and score, diversity points from this movie is shocking.

I was always aware of the Thai Cave rescue but I never truly understood the challenge that the people faced during the rescue. This film succeeds in giving me an appreciation for everyone involved in this rescue. 

Ron Howard delivers a gripping dramatization of the story and manages to keep it suspenseful, despite knowing the resolution. I also appreciate that the movie isn't just about the British Cavers and that the movie gives a lot of focus to what the Thai people die as well. It also helps that all the actors from Viggo, Colin to the Thai actors, give a great performance.

Thirteen Lives is a great retelling of the rescue and I highly recommend it.
Exceptional film! rollercoaster of emotions and amazingly made.
Very good storyline and very inspirational I recommend it a lot!
Gripping. They tell the story in intimate yet broad vistas. I'll watch anything Ron Howard is involved in.
Amazing movie I couldn't stop watching.
10⭐️!!!!! The BEST TRUE STORY HERO FILM IVE SEEN IN MY LIFE!!!!! I remember following this story every single day praying for those boys!!! This will win an Oscar!

Thirteen Lives is a Must See. When this movie showed up in my suggested watches, I was like oh yeah, this seems interesting, and i just hit play. I had totally forgotten that it was a Ron Howard movie, which is almost always a good thing. Well that continues to be true. Howard just knows how to make these movies. I was also surprised by the cast, I didn't know who was in it, and was pleasantly surprised to see Colin Farrell, and Viggo Mortensen, who both transformed into the characters, and were not immediately recognizable. Thankfully Amazon has that awesome feature that tells you the cast members when you hit pause. Anyway the movie was absolutely perfect. I was nervous for much of the movie, even though I thought I knew the outcome. Great performances by all, great cinematography, and direction. 13 Lives is definitely a MUST SEE

I didn't know if I'd want to watch this but did on a recommendation. It was very good. I did find it a little "empty" though, not much of the movie went into any of the stories behind some of the people involved the way I would have liked - it seemed to be more focussed on beating a clock, like in a sporting event.
However It was great seeing how so many people around the world rushed to the aid of these kids and their families. Brought tears to my eyes.
I still can't believe how those divers pulled it all off, it was a miracle.

It's another best movie based on a true story.  Is a movie based on a very good true story, both telling the story from the beginning of the story that the child entered the cave until the end of the story when the child left the cave, this part is very good  The embedded side of the character is considered to be very realistic.  The actors who played various roles were also very good.  Overall, this movie is very good. Anyone who likes this type of movie should not miss it.

This is one of Viggo and Colin's best performances. This movie is an epic retelling of a story that shows grit and strength to push through and be heroes at a level that has never been accomplished before. Ron Howard directs this exhilarating ride into a terrifying reality that twelve young boys and their coach faced for over two grueling weeks. This movie is one of the best films of the year, and based off a true story that is unforgettable.

This should have been released in theaters, it's really a great, beautifully shot movie.  I learned a lot about the rescue from watching the film that I didn't know and it was very entertaining and never dragged.  Must see.

So riveting! I did not know how the story ended, so the anxiety and tension in the film is incredible. I cannot believe what those divers had done to save those boys. Cried at least twice! Five stars!

Most people remember the 12 boys on a soccer team and their coach who were trapped inside a flooded cave in Northern Thailand in 2018. The Rescue was the excellent doc about the event (my review). Director Ron Howard has helmed this "narrative" version that features actors in the re-creation. There is some attention paid to the plight of families and authorities in Thailand, but most of the focus is on the English cave divers who led the effort (played by Colin Farrell, Viggo Mortensen & Joel Edgerton). While this version goes into more deeply into the fascinating procedure, it's also 2.5 hours long. Howard has told the story effectively, but there's surprisingly little emotion on display (the doc did it better). Still, if you haven't "dived" into the deets of this incident, it's an incredible true story of determination.
Well done rescue procedural. Presents lots of issues to think about. Sticks with you.

This movie is my favourite movie of all time. It's not even a movie it's on another level it's a doco-movie. The accuracy, sound design, videography, emotion it was all amazing with the videography and shots being the best I have seen ever I reckon. The accuracy of all the parts of the movie right down to using the same style strecher beds and using umbrellas to shield the boys in the helicopter. The sounds of the tanks hitting the rocks and the gushing water. The emotion you felt as the diver drowned and the life was lost in the cave. As well as many more things. This movie is A++ material and deserves a golden globe for the videography alone
A must watch in your lifetime.
What a fantastic film. It conveys the incredible story of this rescue, and the massive challenges and efforts involved, far better than any news coverage could.
Fabulous movie with outstanding acting and photography. We loved this movie; deserves an Oscar for best picture!
Great! Inspirational.

Great movie. Very intense. Learned so much about the decision making going into the rescue.  The diving scenes were so intense I could feel their emotions and the weight of the challenge.  Even though we knew the outcome, just seeing the thousands of people behind the scene that came together to make the rescues happen, was mind blowing.  Thank God.  It just reminds us there are still genuinely good people all over the world.

Solid, if not a bit overlong rescue drama based on a real event of recent history is fairly suspenseful (most of the audience will remember the actual outcome) and a bit Western-centric concerning the rescue effort; the acting stars were not particularly overburdened with the task to play the heroes.

Great watch! Learned so much about decisions and what happened behind the scenes during that time. The cave diving parts were hard to watch and that means they did a fantastic job filming. I felt the anxiety as if I were in there too. Amazing work by Ron Howard. Just like Apollo 13 - I knew the ending and I was still on the edge of my seat wondering what their fate was.
'Thirteen Lives' is a fantastic and thrilling dramatization of a real rescue incident that celebrates human spirit.

This movie is excellent! I never knew the tremendous odds they were up against, and the way they rescued the boys- I don't remember this being told in the press. Wow!
They were gutsy! Thanks God there are still such people in the world. I hope Thailand better controls access to this cave, especially in the rainy season.
One of the first movies I actually watched all the way through in quite awhile. Great movie.

A great true story but the movie is a bore. There's no suspense at all, the acting of literally everyone is flat, and it's disengaging.  I had to force myself to finish it, hoping it might get better. It didn't.
What a great film of courage and dedication but also so stressful
Ron Howard's best film! He did a great job making sure the story was told accurately. I felt very claustrophobic at times! I absolutely recommend watching it!

Must watch!!!
Excellent technical works, best sound design, best cinematography, best director RH

Thirteen Lives is a 2022 American biographical survival film based on the Tham Luang cave rescue directed and produced by Ron Howard 🤿 

It's ok, but I feel mixed about this one 😉
I'd recommend it if you like this genre, but if not then probably give it a miss 👍🏼👎🏼

This movie does get better as it progresses, but it is too long and repetitive.

5000 PEOPLE, 
17 COUNTRIES, 
1 MIRACLE THAT UNITED THE WORLD.

Great, great movie. Ending is well known (true story) but still is keeping you on the edge of your seat. I would highly recommend it. Great, great movie. 
P.S. 
I don't understand how you can be "Top Reviewer" and get it that wrong like Claudia Puig. I guess you just have to do opposite of more than 90% of other reviewers.
Good film worth the watch

I didnt know much about the actual events of the movie or more specifically, how they actually conducted the operation.  Despite it being 2 1/2 hours, it never felt long.  Loved the movie. Viggo and Colin were great here.
Brilliant film well done amazon, this is the type of film that needs to be in a cinema shows how far streaming services have come. Brilliant acting and I love a true story. 👏👏👏

Good movie about the rescue of thirteen young boys trapped by floodwaters in a cave.  Of course the movie tries to make it seem like everyone is helping out here, but mostly it decries an air of ineptitude on the Thai goverment and their armed forces, while highlighting the need for white guys to come in and save the day.  Don't get me wrong, the enginner that worked the top of the mountain, and the rice farmers unselfishly sacrificing their crops was tremendously compelling, but as for the actual resuce it seemed that the Thai people were mostly helping cook food under tarps on the way into the cave.  This movie also speaks to the exceptionalism of making a risky decision in order to do the right thing, and ultimately proves to be the right thing to do.  These cave divers are super-human in my mind and the Thai goverment should have gotten on their knees to thank them!

I know how this ends and I was on the edge of my seat the entire time. It's a great thriller but an even better human interest story of people from around the world and different communities coming together to rescue these boys and their coach. The performances are stellar as well as the fast paced directing. Best thing Ron Howard has made in a long while and might even be on par with Apollo 13 (I'll let you know after I've watched it 10+ times. Great movie.
A long but well shot film about an incredible real life event. The cave diving scenes we very well made.

Excellent movie! It really makes you feel like you are right there trying to rescue the kids and their coach. And even though I knew the story, I didn't realize what a monumental and dangerous effort this was. True heroes went into that cave to save these lives and it's so great to see the world pull together in this effort. It's nerve-wracking and truly emotional with a great cast and the direction is fantastic.

One of the most exciting rescues that they have given us in recent times is the one brought to the screen by the great Ron Howard in Thirteen Lives. The film based on the tragedy of the children of Thailand, is one of the most exciting surprises of the year and leaves the feeling that it should have been enjoyed longer in cinemas.

A fairly solid recreation is the one that its director offers us about the planning and subsequent development of a rescue that seemed impossible and that ends with a satisfactory ending. Howard manages to take us at all times to the tension of being trapped in a cave for more than 20 days.

The story is supported in a good way on the shoulders of Viggo Mortensen and Colín Farrell who mix well with a totally international cast. With fairly correct performances, the film manages to convey the tension and anguish that such a tragedy means.

The drama grows throughout its 142-minute runtime and that is Howard's virtue that maintains the connection with the viewer throughout its duration, knowing that we all already knew the end of the story. The work that the director and cast do to bring you the reality of a tragedy in the most natural and credible way possible, allows us as viewers to always remain attentive to every detail.

Technically, the work is really surprising, Howard is not limited to putting the camera as one of those who collaborate with the mission and that allows us to experience the anguish from the first person, with great sequences underwater and out of it, in addition to having always that tension on screen without ever losing track of what was at stake.

The surprise ends up being that we find ourselves with a really solid and forceful film, taking the best of those films based on real events, it allows itself to maintain reality, without neglecting the fictional drama that a story brings to the cinema. A great plus achieved by his script and his direction, a story in good hands, always ends up being a good result.

I have watched the documentary, and I believe it was snubbed at the Oscars 2021. It's still the most chilling and emotional documentary I watched last year. This film lacked suspense and felt kind of dry. However, it is still an emotional, gripping, sentimental, and remarkable story from actual life.

remarkable that this movie is based on true events ..claustrophobic catastraphy..lead roles by Farell and Mortison are totally understated..real on location settings and cinema photography..if there is a fault its the long winded run time..just as a side note. I genuinely admire real heroes willing to sacrifice themselves to save others!°
No1 movie of the year. Great real life portrayal of truly heroic men without the usual over dramatized Hollywood hogwash. Very nicely done.
This was a great movie. It's very stressful to watch but definitely worth it. I was crying a little bit at the end of the movie.

Thirteen Lives is a good biographical survival film based on the Tham Luang cave rescue when a group of young kids and there coach got stuck in the cave. When the cave started flooding in from the heavy rain. And a few experienced cave divers are at a race against time to figure out a way to get the kids out. Good plot. Ron Howards direction is good. Showing a rescue team on a desperate search on trying to rescue the kids. Before they lose the air in the caves or starvation. The script did not focus on the kids as much when they were stuck in the caves. Or there struggle on trying to dig there way out which was briefly discussed. The film does show the rescue teams desperate search for solutions on getting into the cave and out with the kids safely. Colin Farrell, Viggo Mortensen, and Joel Edgerton all did great with their roles. The film does get a bit of a thrill and suspense during the rescue mission. It definitely is one of those strong powerful films about survival.

The movie is great and so are the lead actors. However, after watching a couple different versions of this story I would like to see what happens  once the boys are rescued. Also, would like to see the celebrations/honors these brave divers received. Should've ended with actual footage of those things imo to make it five stars.
God bless. Thankful for this movie. Moves me. 🙏🏼 As odd as it sounds. Tremendous healing for me. Amen.

Rating: B-

"Thirteen Lives follows the usual formulas of works based on true events, but Ron Howard's honest, non-Hollywoodized direction allows him to efficiently tell one of the most remarkable survival stories of the last decade.

The entire cast is extraordinary, but it's Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell who mainly guide the film through all the relevant, claustrophobic plot points in a somewhat heavy viewing runtime-wise. Interesting for viewers with little to no knowledge of what happened, but the question remains as to whether it adds anything truly significant to the documentary The Rescue about the same 18 days of suffering, anxiety, and uncertainty.

Massive praise for the worthy amount of screentime of the Thai language."
One of the best movies I have seen this year we all know the ending but shows how many people worked together to save the boys lives

A true tale of modern heroism. It is inspiring to see the depths to which humanity can dig for a solution to a near unsolvable problem such as this. The good: You really feel the weight of importance given to all 13 of the rescued and all of the rescuers as well. Little moments are peppered throughout that really show each character's humanity in a way that is very touching. The bad: It's just too long at 140 minutes. I understand there is a lot to cover and it may have felt disrespectful to trim some of it. But as a film, there is too much of the research and rescue stage that feels similar and ends up mucking up the middle of the movie.
Thirteen Lives succeeds by not making the film about the rescue divers but instead of the actual rescue mission itself.
This is more of a Peter Berg type of film, but Howard pulls it off well. Not the best rescue drama, characters are a bit hollow, but it's worth a watch and has a good ending.

An incredible story with great thematic elements. They did a nice job of keeping the languages authentic which i think added to the story. The fact that this story is true just blows my mind. Colin ferril and Vigo really shine in this piece of work.
Very nicely done. Truly heroic and heart warming. Wonderfull men and boys.
Even though we all know the ending, this movie takes you along the heartfelt journey in such a classy way that respects the boys and the heroic cave divers so well.
Perfect. Perfect. Perfect. The best movie of 2022 by miles.

Amazing boys for their resilience and amazing men risking their lives completing the almost impossible cave dive rescue. This movie captures the drama, emotion and joy  with so much power. Farrel, Edgerton and in particular Viggo Mortensen were simply superb. 10/10
I know how Thireen Lives ends but I had to keep reminding myself of this while I was watching it. A very captivating film.
Amazing story, told well with appropriate tension and emotion.
Excellent Movie!! I'm glad I already knew it had a happy ending because it was pretty intense!
Unbelievable, gripping true story about human resilience when all the odds are against you
It takes talent to produce a story this riveting based on an event in which we all know the outcome. Truly well done!
This movie is absolutly amazing! No CGI, no music - only the powerfull story and this is what it needs. Great, Thanks Ron Howard!

The performances, the story and the direction made this for me.  Would give it a five, but have to save those.  Highly recommended to see the parts you knew about and the parts you may not have.  And an almost meek Colin Farrell.  Would like to see more of that.

Was great! One best movies in a long time.  


  I think the female movie critics of now are clueless and would be better off joining woke protests for daytime job.    Clearly they are all inept and clueless when it comes to what makes a good movie.
Ron Howard has a knack for dramatic real life rescues to make it as a movie. All the actors were great, and they did their own cave dives. Just an amazing true life story with a happy ending.
Breathtaking photography! Even though we knew the story, it was filled with tension to see how it actually happened.  Another Ron Howard tribute to the ingenuity of mankind.

An emotional roller-coaster despite the extraordinarily low key contribution of the British rescue divers, played by Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell. Ron Howard captured the central dilemma: you need the ability to pause fear, pause emotion, to dive through those underground, twisting, mud water filled U bends. The horror of it (awful), the difficulty (beyond extreme), the expectations (sky high) all put on display by the writers, and film director. A film defined by what it left out. No Elon Musk, thank goodness. No silly back stories about each boy on the team. We are plunged into it from the start…and there is additional information we didn't know: the contribution of the water engineers, and the paddy feeds lost under diverted flood waters, for example. Wow.

Wow this movie was incredible to watch. I remember seeing the documentary on Hulu and watching the news about it. Colin Ferrel and Vigo Mortensen did a great job 👏 filming underwater scenes isn’t easy.
Absolutely insane that this rescue worked given all the circumstances and the method used. Decent film.
Incredible movie that doesn't over dramatize a situation to make a "better" movie. Great acting all around, great scenery from shooting, only thing I wanted when the credits rolled was….. more.
Excellent movie very compelling to see how this amazing rescue played out. One of Ron Howard’s best films.

Great feelgood movie, especially if you had no idea how dangerous the rescue was like myself. I sincerely hope that Thailand closed that cave permanently?? It makes absolutely zero sense for 13 human beings to crawl through tiny caverns for one mile down a cave in the earth. Those divers should be in the Guinness Book of World records for doing the impossible. Throughout the entire movie as the divers were barely squeezing through tiny crevices, I was thinking why the heck did these 13 kids crawl down into a cave in a country where it floods every year? At the end of the movie it even said that the caves were flooded for 8 whole months. You cannot tell me this was the first time ever that the cave ever flooded??

Gem of a movie. True life thriller. If you understand anything about diving, let alone cave diving - this was one epic rescue! Hours of diving each way, tight, narrow passages with no chance of turning around in many areas. Murky water with low visability - extremely risky and extremely claustrophobic. WOW.

When Ron Howard makes a film based on true events, his passion is truly felt in every frame, and his latest film, "Thirteen Lives," is no exception. This is a tight and well-made film about a real-life rescue that I knew nothing about. The performances are good and the story grabbed my interest quickly. I felt the movie had to include a lot of events, so there are some days when not a lot of progress is made, but it is still essential to portray the challenge of this operation. However, the movie pays off big with an exceptionally suspenseful final act that had me on the edge of my seat. The movie delivers tension and thrills expertly and had me invested the whole way through. Overall, this is a superb new film that is an exhilarating, inspiring and very well-made story of hope and bravery that hits a lot of the right notes.

Hats off! Incredible view; cave diving is fascinating; so scary, freaking dangerous, and more terrible than a horror movie, but how did those boys still have battery-powered torchlight after so many days? How do those boys get on such a narrow path anyway, but I only saw a single way? Is that another path? Joke of the day: we wait for the rain to stop...

For 18 days in 2018, the world's attention was focused on the attempted rescue of 12 young soccer players and their coach who were trapped inside the flooded Tham Luang cavern in northern Thailand. It was an inspiring story that moved people around the globe, and director Ron Howard has now brought it to life in a technically masterful re-creation. However, as capably made as this picture is, its overlong 2:29:00 runtime can try the patience of viewers at times, especially when some of it sequences become drawn out and repetitive. This is by no means intended to diminish the uplifting nature of the story or the adeptness with which it has been produced cinematically, but, given the emphasis on the picture's technical merits, this approach to telling the tale tends to shortchange its tremendous emotional impact.  A journalistically styled by-the-numbers take on telling a story like this is fine, but I was hoping for something a little more heartfelt in light of the miracle this epically heroic yarn turned out to be. "Thirteen Lives" definitely earns a passing grade, but I can't help but wonder what it might have been with a little more emotion – and a lot more heart-tugging.
Excellent movie, with great values. An act of love and heroism like no other. Deserves an Oscar.
Very good movie.  Starts slow but after10 minutes your all in.  Very exciting and thrilling.  The acting, directing and extras were all top shelf.
Colin Farrell did an amazing job. Had us on the edges of our seats the whole time
If you watch nothing else this year, watch Thirteen Lives and be reminded of what being human means.

True life accounts like this are hard not to make 5 star films, it usually goes without saying.
The thing that spoils a fictional film, is the breaking of the 4th wall: The Dark Knight is one of the best ever movies because, it makes a ridiculous story, real.
True life accounts can only be spoiled by the actors.

Vigor plays a blinder. He is relatable, like your angry uncle who loves you really.

Collin Farrel, I didn't know at first was in the film, so I spent a while judging his common English accent.

However, as the film grew, as you become engrossed, Collins interpretation grows on you. I begun to love his character out of a trust for Colin. It is clear he studied the part, and put his everything into it.

The thing that makes this true story unmissable, is the class A performances that do it justice.

Vigor has form for being an understated ego of an actor.
Colin is an A lister Hollywood star. The way Colins performance disarm you and opens you to his characters plight, is a testimont to Colins skill as an actor.
I'm glad Mr. Howard didn't overdramatize this already horrifying escape. It was a good film about a miraculous event.
Great and refreshing

This movie is clostriphobic, thrilling and absolutely exquisite! This is Ron Howard at his best. Colin Farrell, Viggo Mortensen Joel Edgerton and the entire cast do an absolutely phenomenal job. The actors insisted on doing their own stunts and felt the urgency and horror of this under water nightmare. 
This is an absolute must see. 
Grade A
Love Love this movie!!
Wow absolutely beautiful movie with amazing photography and performances and of course great direction by Howard. Great music and Viggo splendid like always.

it's an incredible, wonderful story of survival, and human achievement, but told oh so blandly... Writer William Nicholson, and director Ron Howard seemed to be overcome, with an acute shyness, for dramatic storytelling.
Will definitely be one to rewatch
Ron Howard should stick to directing soup commercials.
Well done (as you would expect from Ron Howard).  The method of rescue / extraction was quite surprising.
Didn't remember the heroic effort required to rescue these boys. Another feather in Howard's cap of great directing and story telling.
Riveting story. Moving to see humans work together.
Exceptional. Wonderfully acted and Exceptional filming. A must watch and while we know the story it is so well told.

Dry realism with raw drama showing emotions on individual level and mostly devoid of cheap patos. 
Finally a good movie that isn't overblown by unnecessary blockbuster's popcorn action.
Finally, Hollywood manages to recreate an actual event in the world, without over-dramatizing the story surrounding said event.  Mr. Howard did an incredible job.

They stuck to the truth.  They didn't try to over-dramatize. They didn't set up any false narratives. They simply told the truth about hundreds of volunteers, including the divers who risked their lives making a heroic rescue.

Okay, so I've watch 2 different movies on the same topic. The first was the documentary film The Rescue (2021) and just today, I watched Thirteen Lives.  Personally, I'd recommend the documentary, which was not only engaging but realistic without all the unnecessary dramatization that you get from Thirteen Lives. What I didn't like mostly about the Thirteen Lives were the emphasis on drama over the actual rescue mission and how they actually did the rescue, as well as the mediocre acting of some Thai actors, which was baffling as they were pretty well known actors in the Thai industry. When I watched The Rescue, I actually felt like I was there with the divers every step of the way. Thirteen Lives does not really reveal all the interesting details during the dive, the rescue plan and the actual rescue as much as The Rescue, so if you are looking for something realistic, entertaining and educational, go for The Rescue (2021).
Very decent but I suggest you watch the NatGeo doco (The Rescue) before this movie - it is gripping stuff.

Best drama movie I've seen in a long time. For some of the scenes I felt genuine emotion - fear, anguish, anxiety, and sheer joy! Yes I knew how this movie would end, but the acting and directing was top notch. I hope to see this win an Oscar!

Great reenactment of a real event that could have been more tragic. Beautifully filmed in small spaces with brilliant actors. While the run time is long I appreciate that there is not much fluff added. I felt like I was rewatching the news reports from 2018 but much closer.

This rescue drama was very good. Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell, Joel Edgerton, Tom Bateman, Paul Gleeson, and the rest of the cast did a spectacular job in this movie. This true story about the Thai soccer team that got trapped in the underground Tham Luang cave in Thailand during a monsoon was dramatic, intense, and inspirational. It's about never giving up on people that are depending on you to save peoples' lives. If you're an Amazon Prime member, you should watch this movie sometime. It's a definite must see.

Another great Ron Howard emotion packed tear jerker. Accurately told, very believable, amazing he packed in so many events and details into one movie. Characters well developed. You are on the edge of your seat! Bravo.

Good movie. The diving and cave scenes were the best. As a scuba diver who has had a equipment malfunction it really kept my interest even though I knew the outcome. It was a bit too long but since it's steaming it's easy to turn off and on.

Ron Howard delivers again.  It is a great movie that keeps you engaged and emotionally attached from beginning to end.  We need more movies like this (one that doesn't involve a superhero with a cape).

The heroes of this story are the Thai people and a contingent of incredible volunteers around the world. My guess is, you recall the story from the news but don't really know what happened. Ron Howard is truly a legendary director and the cast is stellar. It is harrowing, moving, beautifully shot and memorable. One of the best films of the year.
An absolute nail biter. When you watch this, you won't believe you are only watching a movie.
This is a fantastic movie!  A must see and Ron did a terrific job.
What a story. As usual, Ron Howard tells it best. Incredible ‘against all odds' story about heroes who saved 13 cave trapped boys in Thailand.
Loved it! Fascinating real-life story.  Great cinematography and acting.  Watch it!
My father would always tell me as a boy the life is stranger than fiction. That is definitely true for this true story film. This is an incredible must watch film.

To start, this is great filmmaking on a technical level.
